title: Psalms Chapter 122 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 122 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 122 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 122.

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:1, what made David glad?
options: When they said, Let us go into the house of the LORD
When he saw the city of Jerusalem
When the thrones of judgment were set
questions.correctAnswer: When they said, Let us go into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:1 states David was glad when they said unto him, Let us go into the house of the LORD.

questions.question: Where shall our feet stand according to Psalms 122:2?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:2 says our feet shall stand within the gates of Jerusalem.

questions.question: How is Jerusalem described in Psalms 122:3?
options: As a city that is compact together
As a city surrounded by mountains
As a city of many waters
questions.correctAnswer: As a city that is compact together
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:3 describes Jerusalem as a city that is compact together.

questions.question: Who go up unto the testimony of Israel in Psalms 122:4?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:4 mentions the tribes of the LORD going up unto the testimony of Israel.

questions.question: What are set in the house of David according to Psalms 122:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:5 states there are set thrones of judgment in the house of David.

questions.question: What does Psalms 122:6 instruct us to pray for?
options: Prosperity of the house of David
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:6 commands to pray for the peace of Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:7, what shall be within Jerusalem's walls?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:7 says peace shall be within thy walls.

questions.question: What else, besides peace, does Psalms 122:7 mention will be within the palaces?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:7 mentions prosperity within thy palaces.

questions.question: For whose sake does the psalmist say, 'Peace be within thee' in Psalms 122:8?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:8 says peace is declared for the sake of brethren and companions.

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:9, why will the psalmist seek the good of Jerusalem?
options: Because of the house of the LORD our God
Because of the kings of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the house of the LORD our God
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:9 states the psalmist seeks the good of Jerusalem because of the house of the LORD our God.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 122:1 expresses joy at going to the house of the LORD.
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:1 says, 'I was glad when they said unto me, Let us go into the house of the LORD,' expressing joy.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 122:3 describes Jerusalem as a city scattered and divided.
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:3 describes Jerusalem as a city that is compact together, not scattered.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 122:6 promises prosperity to those who love Jerusalem.
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:6 says they shall prosper that love Jerusalem.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 122:4: 'Whither the tribes go up, the tribes of the ______, unto the testimony of Israel.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:4 states, 'Whither the tribes go up, the tribes of the LORD, unto the testimony of Israel.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 122:2: 'Our feet shall stand within thy ______, O Jerusalem.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:2 reads, 'Our feet shall stand within thy gates, O Jerusalem.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 122 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 122 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 122:1 teach us about the attitude we should have toward worship and gathering with believers?
options: We should be glad and eager to go into the house of the LORD
We should only go when forced
Worship is optional and not important
questions.correctAnswer: We should be glad and eager to go into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:1 expresses joy and gladness when invited to go to the house of the LORD, teaching believers to have a positive and eager attitude toward gathering for worship (verses 1, 4, 6).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with anxiety about their community. Based on Psalms 122, what biblical truth would you share about praying for peace?
options: Pray for the peace of Jerusalem; those who love it will prosper
Ignore the community's problems and focus only on personal issues
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for the peace of Jerusalem; those who love it will prosper
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:6 encourages praying for the peace of Jerusalem and promises prosperity for those who love it, emphasizing the importance of intercessory prayer for community well-being (verses 6, 7, 8).

questions.question: How does Psalms 122:3 describe the unity of believers, and what practical lesson about fellowship can be drawn?
options: Jerusalem is built as a city compact together, teaching unity and closeness among believers
Unity is not important in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem is built as a city compact together, teaching unity and closeness among believers
questions.explanation: Verse 3 depicts Jerusalem as a city compact together, symbolizing unity, which teaches believers to maintain close fellowship and harmony within the church (verses 3, 4, 8).

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:5, what does the presence of thrones of judgment in the city teach us about integrity and justice in leadership?
options: Leadership must be based on righteous judgment and uphold justice
Justice is not important in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Leadership must be based on righteous judgment and uphold justice
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states there are set thrones of judgment in the house of David, highlighting the biblical principle that leaders should exercise justice and integrity (verses 5, 9).

questions.question: What practical encouragement about peace and prosperity can we learn from Psalms 122:7 for our family and home life?
options: Peace and prosperity should be sought within our homes and relationships
Home life is unimportant to God
Peace is only for public places
questions.correctAnswer: Peace and prosperity should be sought within our homes and relationships
questions.explanation: Verse 7 prays for peace and prosperity within the city’s walls and palaces, teaching believers to prioritize peace and well-being in their homes and families (verses 6, 7, 8).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about their role in church fellowship. According to Psalms 122:8, what truth about companionship and mutual support can you share?
options: For the sake of brethren and companions, we should desire peace and unity
Individualism is more important than fellowship
Peace is not related to church fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: For the sake of brethren and companions, we should desire peace and unity
questions.explanation: Verse 8 highlights the importance of praying for peace for the sake of brethren and companions, teaching mutual care and support in the faith community (verses 6, 7, 8).

questions.question: How does Psalms 122:9 connect our love for God’s house with seeking the good of others?
options: Because of the house of the LORD, we should seek the good of our community
Love for God’s house is unrelated to others’ welfare
Our concern should be only personal
Seeking good is a private matter
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the house of the LORD, we should seek the good of our community
questions.explanation: Verse 9 explains that because of the LORD’s house, the psalmist seeks the good of Jerusalem, teaching believers to extend their love for God to care for their community (verses 6, 8, 9).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 122 teaches that physical presence in the house of the LORD is unimportant as long as we have faith.
questions.explanation: Verse 2 emphasizes standing within the gates of Jerusalem, indicating the importance of physically coming together in worship and fellowship (verses 1, 2).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 122, praying for peace benefits both the individual and the community.
questions.explanation: Verses 6 to 8 show that praying for Jerusalem’s peace results in prosperity for those who love it, benefiting both individuals and the community (verses 6, 7, 8).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 122:4 says the tribes of the LORD go up unto the testimony of Israel to give ______ unto the name of the LORD.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 explicitly states that the tribes go up to give thanks unto the name of the LORD, highlighting the importance of gratitude in worship (verses 1, 4).

questions.question: How does the structure of Jerusalem described in Psalms 122:3 encourage believers to cultivate unity in the church?
options: Jerusalem is built as a compact city, encouraging believers to be united closely
Jerusalem is scattered, showing division is acceptable
The city’s structure is irrelevant to unity
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem is built as a compact city, encouraging believers to be united closely
questions.explanation: Verse 3’s description of Jerusalem as compact teaches the value of unity and closeness among believers in the church (verses 3, 8).

questions.question: What does Psalms 122:5 teach about the role of godly authority in maintaining a just community?
options: There are set thrones of judgment in the house of David, showing God’s order in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: There are set thrones of judgment in the house of David, showing God’s order in leadership
questions.explanation: Verse 5 shows that God has established thrones of judgment, emphasizing the importance of godly authority and justice (verses 5, 9).

questions.question: How can Psalms 122:6-7 encourage a believer facing challenges in their workplace or community?
options: Pray for peace and prosperity, trusting God to sustain and bless
Ignore the problems and avoid prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for peace and prosperity, trusting God to sustain and bless
questions.explanation: These verses encourage praying for peace and prosperity, teaching believers to trust God in all areas of life including work and community (verses 6, 7, 9).

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:8, how should love for fellow believers influence our prayers?
options: Love compels us to pray for peace for others
Love means praying only for ourselves
Prayer is not necessary for others
We should avoid praying for companions
questions.correctAnswer: Love compels us to pray for peace for others
questions.explanation: Verse 8 shows that for the sake of brethren and companions, we should pray for peace, illustrating how love moves us to intercede for others (verses 6, 8).

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship can be drawn from Psalms 122:9's emphasis on seeking the good of the city because of the house of the LORD?
options: Our stewardship includes seeking the welfare of our community as part of loving God’s house
We should focus only on personal blessings
Caring for community is unrelated to stewardship
questions.correctAnswer: Our stewardship includes seeking the welfare of our community as part of loving God’s house
questions.explanation: Verse 9 connects love for God’s house with seeking the city’s good, teaching that stewardship includes caring for community welfare (verses 6, 8, 9).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 122 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 122.

questions.question: What emotional response does David express in Psalms 122:1 when invited to go to the house of the LORD?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:1 states, 'I was glad when they said unto me, Let us go into the house of the LORD,' indicating David's joyful response.

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:2, where do the feet of the psalmist stand?
questions.explanation: The verse specifically states, 'Our feet shall stand within thy gates, O Jerusalem,' emphasizing the city as the spiritual center.

questions.question: How is Jerusalem described in Psalms 122:3?
options: As a city that is compact together
As a city by the sea
questions.correctAnswer: As a city that is compact together
questions.explanation: The verse refers to Jerusalem being 'builded as a city that is compact together,' highlighting its unity and strength.

questions.question: Which tribes are mentioned in Psalms 122:4 as going up to Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Whither the tribes go up, the tribes of the LORD,' referring to all Israelite tribes worshipping in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What is set in the house of David according to Psalms 122:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:5 mentions 'thrones of judgment, the thrones of the house of David,' indicating royal authority and judicial power.

questions.question: What does the psalmist urge to pray for in Psalms 122:6?
questions.explanation: The verse commands, 'Pray for the peace of Jerusalem,' emphasizing intercession for the city's well-being.

questions.question: Who will prosper according to Psalms 122:6?
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'they shall prosper that love thee,' meaning those who love Jerusalem will experience prosperity.

questions.question: What two blessings are wished upon Jerusalem in Psalms 122:7?
options: Peace within thy walls and prosperity within thy palaces
Victory in war and many children
questions.correctAnswer: Peace within thy walls and prosperity within thy palaces
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:7 explicitly says, 'Peace be within thy walls, and prosperity within thy palaces,' highlighting security and abundance.

questions.question: For whose sake does the psalmist declare peace upon Jerusalem in Psalms 122:8?
options: For the brethren and companions' sakes
questions.correctAnswer: For the brethren and companions' sakes
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'For my brethren and companions' sakes, I will now say, Peace be within thee,' indicating communal solidarity.

questions.question: Why does the psalmist say he will seek the good of Jerusalem in Psalms 122:9?
options: Because of the house of the LORD our God
Because it is a strategic location
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the house of the LORD our God
questions.explanation: The final verse states, 'Because of the house of the LORD our God I will seek thy good,' connecting the city's welfare to the temple's presence.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 122 is a song of ascent associated with pilgrimage to Jerusalem.
questions.explanation: The heading of Psalms 122 identifies it as 'A Song of degrees,' which were sung by pilgrims ascending to Jerusalem (Psalms 122:1).

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Psalms 122:7 with the phrases 'Peace be within thy walls' and 'prosperity within thy palaces'?
questions.explanation: The verse uses parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, by pairing 'peace' with 'prosperity' and 'walls' with 'palaces' in balanced structure.

questions.question: The phrase 'thrones of judgment' in Psalms 122:5 likely alludes to which Old Testament institution?
questions.explanation: The 'thrones of judgment' refers to seats of legal authority, historically associated with the Sanhedrin, the Jewish council in Jerusalem (Psalms 122:5).

questions.question: The unity of Jerusalem described in Psalms 122:3 reflects which broader biblical theme?
questions.explanation: Jerusalem being 'compact together' symbolizes restoration and unity, themes emphasized in post-exilic writings (Psalms 122:3).

questions.question: Which New Testament event resonates with the pilgrim theme of Psalms 122:1 about going to the house of the LORD?
questions.explanation: Jesus' entry into Jerusalem for Passover parallels the pilgrimage to the temple, echoing the joy of going to the house of the LORD (Psalms 122:1).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 122 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 122 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the initial emotional response of the psalmist when invited to go to the house of the LORD?
questions.explanation: Psalms 122:1 states the psalmist was glad when they said, 'Let us go into the house of the LORD.' This reflects joy in approaching God's presence. Similarly, Isaiah 35:10 and John 4:23 speak of rejoicing in worshiping God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 122, where do the feet of the worshipers stand?
questions.explanation: Verse 2 says, 'Our feet shall stand within thy gates, O Jerusalem,' indicating the sacred place of worship. This aligns with the biblical theme of God's presence in Jerusalem (2 Chronicles 6:6; Luke 24:53).

questions.question: How is Jerusalem described in Psalms 122:3?
questions.explanation: The verse describes Jerusalem as 'builded as a city that is compact together,' emphasizing unity and strength. This is consistent with Ezekiel 48:35 and Revelation 21:3 where Jerusalem symbolizes God's unified people.

questions.question: Who ascends the city of Jerusalem according to Psalms 122:4?
questions.explanation: Verse 4 mentions 'the tribes of the LORD' going up to Jerusalem to give thanks, reflecting the corporate worship of Israel. This is echoed in Deuteronomy 16:16 and Hebrews 12:22 where God's people assemble.

questions.question: What is set in Jerusalem as mentioned in Psalms 122:5?
questions.explanation: The verse states 'there are set thrones of judgment, the thrones of the house of David,' indicating God's righteous rule through David's lineage. This is foundational for messianic expectation (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Luke 1:32).

questions.question: What is the prayer focus for Jerusalem in Psalms 122:6?
questions.explanation: Verse 6 commands to 'Pray for the peace of Jerusalem,' highlighting peace as a divine blessing. Biblical peace (shalom) is a central theme (Isaiah 9:6; John 14:27; Romans 5:1).

questions.question: According to Psalms 122:7, what shall be within Jerusalem’s walls and palaces?
questions.explanation: The verse speaks of 'Peace be within thy walls, and prosperity within thy palaces,' affirming God's blessing on the city. Similar themes are in Jeremiah 29:7 and 3 John 1:2.

questions.question: For whose sake does the psalmist now say, 'Peace be within thee' in Psalms 122:8?
questions.explanation: Verse 8 notes the psalmist's prayer for peace 'for my brethren and companions' sakes,' emphasizing communal concern. This reflects the biblical call to love one another (John 13:34; Romans 12:10).

questions.question: Why will the psalmist seek the good of Jerusalem, according to Psalms 122:9?
options: Because of the house of the LORD our God
Because of the wealth of the city
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the house of the LORD our God
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states the desire to seek Jerusalem's good 'because of the house of the LORD our God,' showing reverence for God's dwelling. This echoes the importance of God's temple (1 Kings 8:48; Acts 7:48).

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s kingship is reflected in the mention of the 'thrones of the house of David' in Psalms 122:5?
options: God rules through the Davidic covenant
God’s kingship is limited to priests
questions.correctAnswer: God rules through the Davidic covenant
questions.explanation: The 'thrones of the house of David' symbolize God's sovereign rule via David's lineage, a messianic theme fulfilled in Christ (2 Samuel 7:16; Luke 1:32-33; Revelation 22:16).

questions.question: How does Psalms 122:6–7 connect to the biblical concept of shalom?
options: By praying for peace and prosperity in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: By praying for peace and prosperity in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 'Pray for the peace of Jerusalem... Peace be within thy walls, and prosperity within thy palaces' express shalom—comprehensive well-being and divine blessing (Isaiah 52:7; Romans 15:33; Philippians 4:7).

questions.question: What ecclesiological insight can be drawn from the gathering of tribes in Psalms 122:4?
options: The unity of God's people in worship
The separation of tribes from each other
questions.correctAnswer: The unity of God's people in worship
questions.explanation: The tribes ascending to Jerusalem symbolize corporate worship and unity in God's covenant community (Acts 2:1-4; Ephesians 4:3-6; Hebrews 10:25).

questions.question: In what way does Psalms 122:9 demonstrate a motivation for intercession for Jerusalem?
options: Because of the house of the LORD our God
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the house of the LORD our God
questions.explanation: The desire to seek Jerusalem's good is rooted in devotion to God's house, highlighting worship as the basis for intercession (Nehemiah 1:4-11; 1 Timothy 2:1-2; Revelation 21:22).

questions.question: What does the psalmist’s gladness in going to the house of the LORD (Psalms 122:1) reveal about the nature of true worship?
options: Worship is a joyful response to God’s presence
Worship is a private affair only
questions.correctAnswer: Worship is a joyful response to God’s presence
questions.explanation: The gladness reflects worship as joy in encountering God (Psalm 100:2; John 4:23-24; Philippians 4:4).

questions.question: How does the description of Jerusalem as 'compact together' in Psalms 122:3 inform the biblical understanding of community?
options: God’s people are called to unity and cohesion
questions.correctAnswer: God’s people are called to unity and cohesion
questions.explanation: The compactness illustrates unity among God's people, consistent with John 17:21 and Ephesians 4:3-6 emphasizing oneness in Christ.
